Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: Do you worry that any of your daughters / sisters could get cancer?  My daughter passed away almost a month ago at only 27.  I am so worried for my younger daughter (24).  She goes for yearly scans but they will not do a mamogram as she is too young.  I also don't want her to go for gene testing as I do not want het to walk around with "a sword over her head".  The new blood test which apparently can pick up breast cancer 4 years earlier than the mamagram, is not available here yet. I would love to hear from you. Love Marietjie Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: family and cancer mpieterse LumiPojo

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: Is there any medication that my daughter can take for not feeling herself?  She has mets to her liver and bones for 18months now and she is struggling this year.  Yesterday was the 1st time that I heard her complain in the almost 4years since the cancer was dx.  She is fed-up with feeling sick all the time.  I hope that there is something (maybe anti-depressants) that will lift her spirit. Lots of love Marietjie  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Feeling down mpieterse mpieterse

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 01:30AM mpieterse wrote: Thanks for your comments.  The picture is very clear to me now. Marietjie
Posts.Title: aspirin mpieterse mpieterse

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: I just read a news clip that aspirin has proven to minimise the risk of breast cancer by something like 20% and that women with bc should take aspirin regularly.  Yet we were told by the onc dept not to take asprin while on chemo.  What do you all think about this? Thanks Marietjie  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: aspirin mpieterse mpieterse

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: My daughter has a very distended stomach.  Because of a runny stomach, we took her to her GP.  I asked about ascetis and was told that the patients are usually yellow and that the stomach is hard and badly swollen, which i was told, was not the case with my daughter.  The GP also said that she could not feel any fluid.  However, a week later, her stomach is still as much distended.  Please can any of you ladies who had/has this problem, let me know if you were yellow and how you found out you had ascetis. Thanks so much. Marietjie Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Ascetis mpieterse waterlily

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: Hi ladies, I need your help please.  My daughter has stage 4 with mets to her liver now the last 18months.  Yesterday she complained for the 1st time saying she is just not feeling well and her whole body is sore.  Not pain for which she has to take pain medication, but her body is not what it used to be.  She is very tired.  What can she take to make her feel better?  She is always so positive, but seems like she is going through a rough time right now. Lots of love Marietjie Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Not feeling well mpieterse cab2004

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: How do you cope with these days when you have lost someone?  Especially the first times eg. birthdays, christmas etc without that person.  I am dreading them as they come closer and need to get myself focused on something which will help me through this.  I would welcome any suggestions. Love Marietjie  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: christmas and special days mpieterse VickiG

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 10:32AM mpieterse wrote: It is today 2 months since my daughter lost her life to bc - she was only 27.  I feel the same and my heart is broken about all the lifes that are stolen by cancer, all the people that is affected by it, all the sadness it is causing.  Yet, I feel blessed that we were able to grow closer to each other, that we could say our good-byes, that we could tell her that we will miss her so much.... Cancer has allowed us this.  I think I will always be mad at cancer. I pray that the Lord will keep each and everyone with this disease very close to his heart. Lots of hugs Marietjie
Posts.Title: DEAR CANCER jeanne46 AccidentalTourist

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 02:36AM mpieterse wrote: I am so sad for you and Steph.  She is a wonderful person and you will have such great memories for youself and your son.  I am thinking of you in this heartbraking time in your life. Lots of hugs Marietjie

Posts.Title: Biopsy results mpieterse desdemona222b

Posts.Content: May 27, 2009 07:25AM mpieterse wrote: Hi Mari, Thanks for your support.  I have lost my eldest daughter last year to bc - she was only 27.  My other daughter (now 25) goes for sonars, mammographs, self-examinations etc.  She had 4 lumps in the one breast and 1 in the other.  The biopsied them and it came back benign.  2 were hurting her and she had then removed yesterday.  The dr said there is a slight chance that they can come back positive.  All of the best to you - will keep in touch to hear how you are doing. Love Marietjie
Posts.Title: Biopsy results mpieterse desdemona222b

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: Morning ladies, I have to get a hookwire procedure before my mastectomy and also an isotope injection.  I want to know how you experienced this - is it painful? One of my biopsies were painful (i have big breasts) and would not like to have the same experience again. Good luck to all who is going for surgery or has just been through it. Hugs Marietjie Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: mpieterse wrote: My daughter, Monica, is struggeling with her liver being sensitive.  She has no energy.  Is there anything that I can give her to improve her energy and something that will work on the liver?  Fortunately, she eats okay.  She is on Gemzar for the past 6months and also gets a Zometa injection monthly.  This discussion board is such a booster for me as I draw so much from each and everyone.  You are all very amazing!!! Hugs Marietjie    Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 15, 2008 08:49AM mpieterse wrote: Hi Susan, She also has liver and bone mets and the area around the liver is sensitive when she touches it.  The onc does from time to time press on her abdomen when he does his check-up. It never felt as sensitive before as much as it does now. On Monday he said that her red blood count was good.    Hugs Marietjie
